prior_works.title: Nonlinear Independent Component Analysis: Existence and Uniqueness Results
prior_works.role: Foundational impossibility result for nonlinear ICA
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established that nonlinear ICA is not identifiable without additional assumptions, motivating the need for structural inductive biases such as the additive decoder constraint used to obtain identifiability here.

prior_works.title: Variational Autoencoders and Nonlinear ICA: A Unifying Framework
prior_works.authors: Ilyes Khemakhem; Diederik P. Kingma; Ricardo Pio Monti; Aapo Hyvärinen
prior_works.role: Positive identifiability framework for nonlinear ICA with auxiliary variables
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed identifiability of nonlinear ICA in VAEs under conditional exponential family assumptions and side information; the present work extends the landscape by proving identifiability for additive decoders without auxiliary variables and under weaker assumptions on latent distributions.

prior_works.title: Challenging Common Assumptions in the Unsupervised Learning of Disentangled Representations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated that disentanglement is impossible without inductive biases, directly motivating the paper’s use of additive architectural bias to obtain provable identification.

prior_works.title: Attend, Infer, Repeat: Fast Scene Understanding with Generative Models
prior_works.authors: S. M. Ali Eslami et al.
prior_works.role: Pioneering object-centric generative modeling with additive masked decoders
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced object-centric decoders that reconstruct scenes by summing per-object images through masks; the current paper formalizes identifiability guarantees for this additive family.

prior_works.title: MONet: Unsupervised Scene Decomposition and Representation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Popularized additive masked reconstruction for multi-object images, directly inspiring the additive decoder class whose identifiability and extrapolation properties are analyzed theoretically here.

prior_works.title: IODINE: Iterative Object Decomposition Inference Network
prior_works.role: Object-centric model with per-slot reconstructions and additive compositing
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Uses slot-wise masked decoders whose summed outputs reconstruct scenes; the paper’s results provide the missing theoretical underpinning for identification in such additive decoders.

prior_works.title: Independent Subspace Analysis
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced identification up to permutation and block-wise indeterminacies, paralleling the paper’s guarantee of identifying blocks of latents up to block-wise invertible transforms.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core innovation—provable identification of latent variable blocks using additive decoders and consequent Cartesian-product extrapolation—sits at the intersection of nonlinear ICA theory and object-centric representation learning (OCRL). Classical results by Hyvärinen and Pajunen established that nonlinear ICA is not identifiable without additional structure, setting the conceptual challenge this work addresses. Khemakhem et al. later showed that identifiability can be recovered by leveraging auxiliary variables under conditional exponential family assumptions; this paper complements and broadens that line by proving identifiability in a different regime: exact reconstruction with additive decoders and only weak assumptions on latent distributions, eschewing side information. Locatello et al.’s impossibility result for unsupervised disentanglement further underscored the necessity of inductive biases, motivating the explicit additive architectural constraint.
On the modeling side, OCRL methods such as AIR, MONet, and IODINE introduced additive (mask-based) decoders that reconstruct images by summing per-object contributions. The present work abstracts this additive compositionality and provides rigorous guarantees for latent identification in such decoders, thereby offering theory that underwrites widely used OCRL practices. Finally, the identifiability result’s form—recovery up to permutation and block-wise invertible transformations—echoes Independent Subspace Analysis, connecting the contribution to established block-identifiability notions. Together, these strands yield a principled route to both identifiable representations and out-of-support generation via recombining object-specific latents (Cartesian-product extrapolation).
